eecs2311.project

Class BrailleCell

  • java.lang.Object
    • eecs2311.project.BrailleCell

  • public class BrailleCell
extends java.lang.Object
    This class groups 8 JRadioButtons into a Braille Cell. A 'selected' radio button represents a raised pin, while a non-selected radio button represents a lowered pin. The class contains methods for displaying letters on the cells as well as raising and/or lowering individual pins.

    By default, this class supports basic alphabet + the space character using the displayCharacter() method. The predetermined characters are displayed using standard Braille. For any non-standard characters or ones that aren't included by default, use the setPins() method, which takes a string of 1s and 0s as argument and sets the pins accordingly. 1 meaning raised and 0 meaning lowered.

    Author:
    Team 4: Yassin Mohamed, Qassim Allauddin, Derek Li, Artem Solovey.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BrailleCell

        public BrailleCell(javax.swing.JRadioButton radio1x1,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio1x2,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio2x1,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio2x2,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio3x1,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio3x2,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio4x1,
                   javax.swing.JRadioButton radio4x2)
        Class constructor, initializes the class's 8 radio button variables as the ones passed into the constructor. The arguments and the class parameters have the same reference to allow the class to alter the state of the radio buttons.

        Radio buttons can be thought of as occupying a 4x2 grid, with each button having index Row x Coloumn starting with 1x1 on the top-left.

        Parameters:
        radio1x1 - radio button at position 1x1
        radio1x2 - radio button at position 1x2
        radio2x1 - radio button at position 2x1
        radio2x2 - radio button at position 2x2
        radio3x1 - radio button at position 3x1
        radio3x2 - radio button at position 3x2
        radio4x1 - radio button at position 4x1
        radio4x2 - radio button at position 4x2

    • Method Detail

      • displayLetter

        public void displayLetter(char a)
        Displays the character passed as argument on this Braille Cell object in Braille.

        The method works by selecting specific radio buttons that represent raised "pins", or the parts of the letter that would be felt by a human hand.

        Parameters:
        a - the character to be displayed in Braille
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the character isn't part of the standard alphabet or a space character.

      • setPins

        public void setPins(java.lang.String pins)
        Takes an eight character string of 1s and 0s as argument, and sets the eight radio buttons that represent the pins in the braille cell to either true or false, depending on the String passed.

        The 8 character string of 1s and 0s sets the state of the eight radio buttons. Depending on the value of the character in the String, the corresponding radio button is set. The first character corresponds to the top-left radio button, the next character corresponding to the next radio button from left to right and top to bottom.

        Parameters:
        pins - string of 1s and 0s that is 8 characters long that sets the state of the eight radio buttons that form the cell
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the string is not 8 characters long or if it contains any character that isn't a 1 or a 0

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Sets all the radio buttons' selected state to false, effectively clearing the cell of whatever it was displaying.

        This is equivalent to displayLetter(' ') .
